overview_summary: Of the three profiled neighbors, one has openly supported renewable energy development, while the other two have no documented stance. None of these landowners hold public office or formal power in the community, and there are no high-influence neighbors identified among them.

neighbors.name: Jason & Tracy Thornock
neighbors.claims: Jason and Tracy Thornock own a third-generation cattle and hay ranch in Cokeville, Lincoln County, Wyoming [Wyoming Public Media](https://www.wyomingpublicmedia.org/natural-resources-energy/2025-12-17/ranchers-hoping-solar-can-lower-costs-say-utilities-and-the-state-stand-in-their-way). Jason Thornock has publicly advocated for the ability to use solar power to offset an approximately $150,000 annual electric bill on the ranch, criticizing the utility as a 'government-protected monopoly' under current state rules [Inside Climate News](https://insideclimatenews.org/news/14122025/cokeville-wyoming-ranch-scale-solar/). In 2014, the Thornocks sued neighboring landowners seeking a private road for easier ranch access, but Wyoming courts denied the request after finding the property was not truly landlocked [Justia](https://law.justia.com/cases/wyoming/supreme-court/2016/s-15-0273.html).

approach_recommendations.engage: Highlight how the project can reduce their ranch’s high energy costs and secure its future for their children. Engage Jason through a fellow rancher or local leader he trusts, emphasizing local involvement and fair terms to address his distrust of outside control.

neighbors.name: Justin & Jamie Mckinnon
neighbors.claims: Justin and Jamie Mckinnon operate McKinnon Livestock, a cattle ranch business based in Cokeville, Wyoming since about 2004 [Buzzfile](https://www.buzzfile.com/business/McKinnon-Livestock-307-279-2177). USDA records indicate that Justin Mckinnon received roughly $127,000 in federal livestock disaster assistance from 1995 to 2024, reflecting the family’s active ranch operations in the Cokeville area [EWG Farm Subsidy Database](https://farm.ewg.org/top_recips.php?fips=56023&progcode=total_elap&regionname=LincolnCounty,Wyoming).
neighbors.influence_justification: Local ranch family; no public role

approach_recommendations.engage: Meet the Mckinnons informally at their ranch, emphasizing that the development will not disrupt their cattle operation. Highlight any measures to preserve agricultural land and explain how the project could indirectly support the local ranching community’s future.

neighbors.name: Monte Mckinnon
neighbors.claims: Monte Mckinnon is part of a longstanding Cokeville ranching family—local records show the Mckinnon name in the community since at least the 1920s [Genealogy Trails](http://genealogytrails.com/wyo/lincoln/cokevillecem.html). He holds property via a family trust and has maintained a low public profile, with no noted involvement in local development or energy debates.

approach_recommendations.engage: Approach Monte through his family (e.g., via Justin) with respect for his privacy. Assure him that the project will not impair his quiet rural lifestyle and may help to sustain the family’s ranching legacy for future generations.
